ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Built off skills from 110, weather, traveling, dating, renting an apartment, ordering food, etc.

I learned new vocabulary in addition to 100 more characters from last semester. We also learned more complex sentence structures, such as making comparisons, all-inclusive/all-exclusive statements, adding details to past events (where, when, with who), etc.
I gained a deeper understanding of Chinese language.
Beginner intermediate Chinese.
I expanded my understanding of Chinese grammar as well as my vocabulary.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A major strength is the amount of rigor in every class. From all the activities we do in class to the homework assignments and the extra meetings with the professor or your TA, you will leave this class being very fluent. However, this class does meet every day, which can be very exhausting over time.
The strengths were that the classes were interactive, helping you learn.
Its very engaging and rigorous. However, its a bit too concentrated.

I like that the course meets every day. I like that the homework is planned well ahead of time. I already like the course the way it is and cannot really think of major weaknesses. Maybe if anything, getting comments on our Quia homework would be nice.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The Zoom structure worked fine because the professor would call on people to read things on the slides or to answer her questions. There would be some technical difficulties that made it hard to communicate clearly.
The live interactive classes helped.
Unlike CHNS 110, we didnt practice in groups that much.
I think it was good to have the lectures all online.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Certainly! This is an incredible introduction to Mandarin. After only two semesters I'm very happy and proud of how much I was able to learn.
Yes, but in person.
Yes! Its similar in structure to 110, so chances are youll already be in a rhythm. I feel like my Chinese has improved a lot.

I would definitely recommend this course. The Chinese sequence is one of Yale's strongest programs, and after two semesters you'll leave knowing a great deal of Chinese. CHNS 120 is especially helpful because it really introduces you to complex sentence structures and vocabulary in a way CHNS 110 didn't do necessary (of course, because CHNS 110 is the very first time people are introduced to Chinese). If you're even remotely interested in learning how to speak Chinese, TAKE CHNS 110 AND THIS COURSE!
Yes, if a student is greatly interested in the Chinese language.
If you want to learn Chinese, go for it!
Yes, I think the teacher is excellent and is willing to always be there to help you learn.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also had weekly individual sessions with the professor and weekly tutorials with TAs.
None.
